title: Fix assignee + mail recipient lists (use agents, not squads)
description:
Problem

- assets/src/routes/mail.tsx: ComposeModal toggles recipients using squad.name.

Impact
- Tickets can only be assigned to squad names (not agents).
- Mail can be addressed to squad names that backend may not recognize as recipients.
design: Derive a project-scoped agent list by flattening squads: useSquads(projectId).data?.flatMap(s => s.agents ?? []). If backend does not preload agents, add an API endpoint + hook to fetch agents. Update assets/src/components/board/TicketFlow.tsx and assets/src/routes/mail.tsx to use the agent list.

- Assignee dropdown lists agents for the active project
- Mail compose recipient picker lists agents and sends successfully

title: Agent detail: align session status + mailbox participant filtering
description:
Problem
- Agent detail uses different session-status logic than the dashboard and likely filters mail threads using the wrong identifier.

Evidence
- assets/src/routes/index.tsx counts sessions with status == running.
- assets/src/routes/agent.$agentId.tsx searches for status == active.
- assets/src/routes/agent.$agentId.tsx filters MailThread.participants using agentId, but MailMessage uses sender_name/to (names), so participants are likely names.

Impact
- Agent detail can show IDLE/no session even when a session is running.
- Agent mailbox can appear empty even when there are threads.
design: Confirm backend session status values and standardize predicates across routes. Decide canonical identifier for mail participants (agent id vs name); update UI filtering accordingly. Prefer real agent data (name/slug/model) over placeholder fallback.
acceptance_criteria:
- Agent detail shows correct ACTIVE/IDLE state based on real sessions
- Agent mailbox shows threads where the agent participates
- Session status predicate is consistent across dashboard and agent detail

title: Mail route: remove window.innerWidth branching; make responsive via CSS/hook
description:
Problem
- Mail route branches on window.innerWidth during render to decide which panes to show. This is non-reactive (layout will not update on resize) and brittle.

Evidence
- assets/src/routes/mail.tsx uses (!selectedThreadId || window.innerWidth >= 768) in render logic.

Impact
- Layout can get stuck when resizing or when opening threads on different viewport sizes.
design: Refactor assets/src/routes/mail.tsx to rely on Tailwind breakpoints for desktop vs mobile (md:hidden, md:flex) and use state only for mobile navigation. If a hook is preferred, implement a small useMediaQuery that subscribes to matchMedia changes.
acceptance_criteria:
- Resizing viewport updates mail layout without reload
- No window.innerWidth usage in render
- Mobile navigation (folders/list/thread) remains predictable and state-driven

title: Modal: prevent double onClose and harden <dialog> lifecycle
description:
Problem
- Modal uses a <dialog> with an effect that calls dialog.close() plus a close event listener that calls onClose. This can double-trigger onClose (especially when parent-driven isOpen changes call dialog.close()). showModal() can also throw if invoked while already open.

Evidence
- assets/src/components/Modal.tsx: effect toggles showModal/close; separate addEventListener("close", ...) calls onClose.

Impact
- Duplicate form resets, duplicate notifications, or flickery state when closing modals.
design: Gate showModal/close using dialog.open and try/catch around showModal. Only call onClose for user actions (ESC/backdrop/close button) or make it idempotent. Prefer dialog onCancel/onClose props over manual addEventListener where possible.
acceptance_criteria:
- onClose fires exactly once per user-initiated close (ESC/backdrop/close button)
- Parent-driven isOpen changes do not cause duplicate close callbacks
- No console errors when rapidly opening/closing

title: Consolidate cn() helper across UI
description:
Problem
- Multiple cn() helpers exist with different behavior (clsx+twMerge vs simple join), which leads to inconsistent class merging and duplicated code.

Evidence
- assets/src/routes/__root.tsx defines cn() using clsx + tailwind-merge.
- assets/src/routes/index.tsx defines a simple join-based cn().
- assets/src/routes/squad.tsx defines another join-based cn().

Impact
- Tailwind class conflict resolution differs between screens, making UI changes unpredictable.
design: Create a shared util (e.g. assets/src/lib/cn.ts) exporting cn(...). Use clsx + twMerge. Replace local helpers with imports. Keep usage consistent across routes and components.
acceptance_criteria:
- Single cn() implementation shared across routes/components
- No local cn() definitions remain
- Class merging behavior is consistent (twMerge applied everywhere)

title: UI animations: configure or replace non-core Tailwind animate classes
description:
Problem
- Components reference animation utility classes that are not Tailwind core (e.g., animate-in, animate-out, slide-in-from-right-full, fill-mode-forwards). Unless configured, these are no-ops and intended motion feedback is missing.

Evidence
- assets/src/components/Notifications.tsx uses animate-in/slide-in-from-right-full and animate-out/fade-out.
- assets/src/components/board/TicketFlow.tsx uses animate-in/fade-in/slide-in-from-right-4.

Impact
- Toasts and overlays appear abruptly; the UI feels less polished and status feedback is weaker.
design: Choose one approach: (A) add a Tailwind animation utilities plugin compatible with Tailwind v4, or (B) implement keyframes in assets/src/index.css and replace classnames. Audit all uses of animate-* and slide-in-* utilities.
acceptance_criteria:
- Toasts and overlays animate as intended
- Animation approach is consistent (plugin vs CSS keyframes)
- No stray non-configured animation classes remain in the codebase

title: A11y pass: label icon buttons + keyboard dismiss for menus
description:
Problem

Evidence
- Icon-only buttons: sidebar close, hamburger menu, more menus, dropdown toggles, etc.
- Many menus use a fixed inset click-catcher div but do not handle Escape or focus management.

Impact
- Poor screen-reader UX and weak keyboard support across core screens.
design: Audit key routes (sidebar/nav, squad, board, mail, review) and add aria-labels. Add Escape handlers for dropdowns/menus and ensure focus styles remain visible.
acceptance_criteria:
- Icon-only buttons have aria-labels
- Escape closes dropdowns/overlays and modals predictably
- Focus ring and tab order is usable on main screens (sidebar, board, mail, squad)

Auto-rebuild frontend assets on change during development
description:
## Problem

Currently, frontend asset changes (React/TypeScript in assets/src/) require a manual `npm run build` to update priv/static/assets/. Phoenix's live_reload watches priv/static/ but Vite dev server serves from memory, not disk.

## Current Setup
- `config/dev.exs` runs `npm run dev` which starts Vite dev server (port 5173)
- Vite dev server proxies /api to Phoenix (port 4000)
- Phoenix serves SPA from priv/static/assets/ (built by `npm run build`)
- Phoenix live_reload watches priv/static/*.js|css

## The Gap
When code changes in assets/src/:
- Vite dev server at :5173 picks up changes immediately (HMR)
- BUT Phoenix at :4000 serves stale priv/static/ assets
- Developers accessing :4000 see old code until manual rebuild

## Solutions (Pick One)

### Option A: Use vite build --watch (Recommended)
Change `npm run dev` to run `vite build --watch` which continuously rebuilds to priv/static/:

```json
// assets/package.json
"scripts": {
  "dev": "vite build --watch",
  ...
}
```

Pros: Simple, works with Phoenix live_reload, one port (:4000)
Cons: Slower rebuilds than HMR, no HMR

### Option B: Configure Phoenix to serve Vite dev assets
In dev, have Phoenix proxy to Vite for assets. Complex but enables HMR.

### Option C: Document the two-server workflow
Keep current setup, document that developers should access :5173 for frontend work.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Asset changes reflected in browser within seconds during development
- [ ] Single command (mix phx.server) starts everything needed
- [ ] Works reliably without manual intervention

- Streaming logic is centralized and testable in one module.

Acceptance:
- All session endpoints return a consistent opencode_error payload and status.
- SessionController no longer contains duplicated opencode_error branches.
